I chose to spend $50 more for its better "surround" sound - good enough that I don't have to buy a sound bar. It certainly was the right decision as far as the sound goes - good enough for a 15ft x 20ft family room.The plasma display is very good. It is bright (brighter than my 50" THX-certified LG) and its picture is sharp.I mount it on the wall using a low-profile mount. It weighs about 50lbs, which is a lot easier to handle for one person than other TVs in its class!The only thing that might be an issue for some folks is its reflective glass. During the day with bright sunlight, I can see the reflection from the screen clearly when the TV is off. Much less when it's on because the TV is quite bright.Family members are pleased - a beautiful TV to make family room nice place for casual TV viewing, without breaking the bank.

Reviews.Title: Audio outputs
Reviews.Author: S. L. Valent
Reviews.Content: Advertised as having a analog audio output but it only has an optical audio output so be aware that you will need an adaptor.UPDATE:  After only 6 months the plasma screen cracked.  Samsung refuses to repair saying it was "physical damage". Yes, physical damage caused by thermal expansion of the screen. It is a well known problem, I now have a $700 paper weight.  Do yourself a favor and Google Samsung cracked plasma screen.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Undecided Major
Reviews.Content: Only have had it for a few days, but so far I LOVE IT. Great TV, great deal...... life is good. Amazon simply rocks. Loved the white glove delivery by CEVA who called to tell me when they were coming a few days later and came when promised. They removed from box, set it up, made sure it worked well, showed me some basic features and asked if I wanted the empty box removed. Hassle free, and a great TV!!!!!!! Get one!! :)

Reviews.Title: Great Plasma TV (with issues.. for me, at least)
Reviews.Author: Philip J. Park
Reviews.Content: Just want to say how impressed I was with this TV. I replaced my ANCIENT 51" projection TV from the 90's after the colors were offset (it served us well though). The video quality (depending on its source)is as good as it can be on a 720p TV. I am currently watching the Man U vs. Barcelona match live and the refresh rate is stunning.. man, I can't wait for the football (both NFL & Premier League) season to start!My problem is that the technical description on Amazon is a little deceptive. it says something about a PC input but I can't find it, unless they're considering the HDMI as a PC input. I was hoping for a DVI or VGA connection so I could hook up more HDMI sources but that didn't happen. FINE. At least I could use the USB port to playback my video files like the technical description says, right? WRONG! This model being a low-end model, it doesn't support video playback via USB (it only supports Photos & Music).Overall, I'm very satisfied with the purchase. I watched a couple of DVDs and Blurays to check out the quality and it's great! I mean, C'MON! you can get 2 of these for the price of one 1080p. It's $650 (with free shipping) for a 51" TV from a quality brand.

Reviews.Title: Best tv for the money
Reviews.Author: everlasting1832
Reviews.Content: 1 Word. SAMSUNG...#1 tv company...The color and contrast ratio on this tv is stunning...I love 720p vs 1080p because when i watch standard definition tv or even DVD's they still look sharp and crispy not all smudged up like 1080p and then when i watch HD the 720 kicks in and really I cannot tell the difference between 1080p not until you look really really close. This tv looks great playing call of duty modern warfare 2...the only downfall about this tv is only 2 hdmi ports and only and optical audio out which makes it harder to find a home theatre system...only new hometheatres can hook up to optical inputs/outputs. get the namebrand and the quality for a good price..i recommend this tv.

Reviews.Title: Ode to a Plasma TV
Reviews.Author: Daniel Wilson
Reviews.Content: I grew up in the age of CRT,It seemed quite good to me,Yet I have heard of late,A technology described as great,That shows a picture more profound,With vibrant colours that astound,But I did so love my CRT,The old reliable technology,Still my friends did insist,Alas, I could not resist!And so fate I tempted,Since, I have but lamented,All the many years wasted on thee,Ailing, aged, and pathetic CRT,Now I know true joy,With my new televisual toy,I will watch until I can watch no more,All videos with plasmonic glory galore!

Reviews.Title: Great TV, just not for me.
Reviews.Author: MChief576
Reviews.Content: I recently moved to a house, which has a bigger living room.  I have a 40" Samsung 720p LCD, which I still love.  I just wanted something bigger.  After several weeks of research, I decided to buy this Samsung Plasma.  I read lots of online discussions regarding the issues with Plasmas: Image Retention, Sun Glare and the break in period.  I contacted Samsung regarding the break-in period, they said this TV does not need a break in period.  The TV also has built in Screen Burn-in protection and is Energy Star Compliant.  Plus, I couldn't ignore the amazing price, free shipping and great reviews.Amazon shipped the TV within 3 days.  The movers brought the TV upstairs and made sure it worked.  As soon as I turned it on, the picture was great.  Even though its a 720p, its an amazing picture.  The plasma appears to be a nicer picture then my LCD.  I can't comment on the sound, since I use a HTIB.  At first I was very happy with my purchase.  I have 3 large windows to the right of the TV; sun glare was not an issue.  Unfortunately, there is one major item I did not notice when researching Plasma's - Reflection.  Anytime there is a dark image or color, I can see my reflection, the couch and anything else in front of the TV.  I thought it was because of all the windows in the room.  But, I can even notice my reflection at night, with no lights on.  I had some friends over to get their opinion.  All of them noticed the reflection, but it didn't bother everyone.  For me, I find it distracting.  This will be going back to Amazon.  Too bad, the TV produces a great picture.

Reviews.Title: Stopped playing
Reviews.Author: Mary Ann "Mary Ann"
Reviews.Content: After 2 years and 1 month the picture went completely black and won't come back up. Tv still has sound. You can no longer buy this model, and I guess for good reason. But I also wonder how long the other Samsung plasma televisions will play without having a major issue such as mine!

Reviews.Title: Deserves 5 stars, but I'm bitter right now...
Reviews.Author: Shawn
Reviews.Content: Was a great TV right up until it broke two weeks after the warranty expired.  If Samsung will still honor the warranty, then I will give it more stars and continue to buy Samsung products.  If not, then I'll leave it at 1 star and forever curse the name Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Great TV, misleading product page
Reviews.Author: Nadav Samet
Reviews.Content: When I read the technical details on this product page, I had no doubt it fits my needs. Ethernet port, PC input, USB port that play videos and more. Yeah, it's only 720p, but a 51'' Samsung TV with these specs for $645 is quite a bargain.The TV arrived and I was (and still am) very satisfied of its quality, size and color depth. No question about that.However, I was disappointed of the misleading details that I read on the page. I found out there was neither Ethernet port, nor PC input. Only HDMI ports, component and optic inputs. The USB, of course, could only play music or show images. No video option exists nor a way to upgrade the firmware. I spent an hour on the line with a special Samsung technician that gave up saying that he can't find a way to do it.The bottom line is that the TV is great, but know what you order, ensure it ships with the components you wish for, and see if it's worth the price after that being take into account.

Reviews.Title: Great TV for a light controlled room. 720P is not a problem at this size
Reviews.Author: Kyle E. Henderson
Reviews.Content: When I was searching for TV's I had a budget of $1000. I researched for a lot longer than I should have looking at LCD's vs. Plasmas vs. LED/LCD's. I wanted a TV that would give me the most accurate colors, best image quality, best gaming experience (Xbox 360), and best movie watching experience. Time and time again I saw that Plasmas deliver the best for these uses. You go to Best Buy or some other big box retailer and see all the TV's on the wall and the LED/LCD's look the best by far. But that's because they're on super eyeball-bleeding brightness because those stores are so bright. The Plasmas look terrible there. But bring a good Plasma back home and put it in your living room and it will give you amazing colors, rich blacks, and amazing detail. LED/LCD's for the most part make things look to fake I think. Anyway, I ended up with this TV for about half my budget price and couldn't be happier. The community at Avsforum.com is what won me over. Everyone raves about how good the panel is in this cheap TV. And they're right. I've had this TV for about a year now and its been awesome. 720P, even at 51in, looks great. You seriously won't see the difference unless you're watching a Blu-Ray movie that is very graphically intense and made for Blu-Ray watching. If you have this TV you really need to check out the owners thread at avsforum.com for calibration specs and details: [...]Only con I can think of about this TV is that it does NOT have normal audio out. The only audio out is optical. At this point I'm sure there are newer and cheaper models but this TV has been great. (I see its $749 right now, I got it for around $500 last year).

Reviews.Title: Amazing TV
Reviews.Author: Jesse13
Reviews.Content: I've had the tv for over a year now and it still operates like a champ. I know that there are people that complain about certain features about the TV, like the usb hook up and internet user interface, but if you want a TV for a great price (got mine for 500) then this is your TV.It does well what a TV is supposed to do. To be honest i have this thing hooked up to my receiver so i can't vouch for the TV speakers but again if you're just looking for a great TV then this is your buy. No big TV is going to have amazing speakers built into it for less than a couple grand, so screw that haha.

Reviews.Title: Incredible Value
Reviews.Author: TSR3000
Reviews.Content: Bought two of these bad boys.  Samsung is my brand for tvs.  This tv does the job.  Great picture, good sound and amazing value.

Reviews.Title: Samsung PN43D450 43" 720 Plasma TV
Reviews.Author: dj lucky two
Reviews.Content: This TV is just great. Did not really trust Plasma TV's with all the bad rep. they where getting. This model is just great for my living-room. The only bad thing about it is that it does not have a audio output in the back to connect to your stereo.  It does not have the red and white connecters to connect your stereo. Besides that, the TV is just great. The sound is a lot better than expected. It was given to me as a gift and I am loving it except for that one problem.

Reviews.Title: Little details that matter
Reviews.Author: Guillermo
Reviews.Content: Some things you would not know until you use this:1. Image quality is superb. No need to pay extra for 1080p.2. Aspect Ratio is a little wide compared to other TVs.3. Sound is OK. Not bad, not impressive. You should use an additional sound sysyem with any TV of this size, anyway.4. Sleep function is not good, the minimum setting is 30 minutes, next is 60. I find this very annoying, as I like to set the timer to only 10 minutes.5. Remote control range is terrible. You have to point the remote directly to the screen in order to get a good signal. Even then, buttons are hard to use and you cannot press the buttons several times in a row and do what you intended. The delay is terrible.Overall, this is a great buy. I paid $649.00 on Amazon and Im happy with my purchase. 51 inches and great image quality for less than $700 is hard to beat.

Reviews.Title: Only minor quirks
Reviews.Author: ColtonMilne
Reviews.Content: I purchased this tv on sale at best buy for $425 a few weeks before black friday and i am thoroughly impressed for what i payed for it. i waited until now (March 3, almost 4 months later) to write this review just to see how it performed over time.Pro's:Great Picture, Great Price, Deep Blacks, Vivid colors, amazing sound for a flat screen, very thin for a plasma, small bezel, Aesthetically pleasing.Con's:TV does have a minor "buzz" sound while on, but as long as you are playing a game or watching tv or a movie you dont notice it. this is the only downside that i have noticed.Overall, AMAZING tv for the money. almost as thin as a LED, but with better lighting and picture quality. Plasmas are still the best for sports and movies (although LCD has gotten better) and burn in issues are almost nonexistent anymore. i would recomend this product to anyone in the market for a low price flat screen.

Reviews.Title: F'n sweet
Reviews.Author: mattyboy
Reviews.Content: This Plasma is awesome I use it for my PS3 and Xbox 360 if you are iffy on getting this just get it trust you won't regret it its pretty sweet.It works pretty well with my Ps3 i can turn my PS3 on and by doing that the tv will turn on as well and even switch to the right channel source for the PS3 if it isnt on there already.

Reviews.Title: Amazing for the price
Reviews.Author: C. Smth
Reviews.Content: Been stuck choosing between LCD/LED/Plasma. After much comparison, great reviews and seeing this on sale at BB for $399 I had to give it a try. The whites looked weak in store compared to LED but the colors were so rich and the contrast was great. As I looked at LED/LCD I saw even top end models show strange artifacting and breakup in certain screens like smoke or fog, or lights shinning thru smoke, etc...but most all Plasma's looked perfect showing same. Set up was a breeze. Did some tinkering and found the Dynamic mode which really makes this TV pop. After some more calibration, I have the whites looking pure and the blacks go as deep as the frame color, this TV amazes everyone who sees it. Only 720p? Wow...and it's not even really a full 720p, how did Samsung pull this one off? Played Rio on BD and never seen such a great PQ, and BD of Titanic blew me away. Then I tossed in the DVD (upconverted) of Dick Tracy, this movie will test color contrast to the max, it's one of the best test movies to use as the sets are the most unusually vivid colors, anyway, it looked so good it almost overides the bad acting, then played the Crazy88's scene of Kill Bill, the colors and contrast showed every detail. These new Samsung Plasma TV's are just amazing, unless you have a bright room... then the reflections on screen and washed out colors dont do it justice. Also it looks really quality when off too.

Reviews.Title: Beware, this not on a PN43D450 it's for.....
Reviews.Author: 6lumbar
Reviews.Content: It is for PN51D450A2D, after reading these reviews I see there are 2 different models which is causing some confusion.It seems the PN43D450 is getting all bad reviews and (now we see why)  PN51D450 is getting the good reviews, not sure why Amazon allows reviews for a different model.I went to Samsung and found a link that might help you folks who purchased models PN43D440, 450, 490. There is firmware update for your sets:[...]For the PN51D450, I am very happy with the picture quality, the sound is very good after some adjusting, the cons, NO swivel base, cheap remote, no light, needs more HDMI AV inputs.

Reviews.Title: Awesome TV
Reviews.Author: edwards
Reviews.Content: It is the perfect 51 inch. Is large and and thinner than I thought it would be. I weighs about 60 pounds which is good for a plasma and the color is great. Reviews.Title: Best plasma under $500

Reviews.Content: I bought this TV ($399) with eager anticipation knowing it had a great reputation and glowing reviews for what it was: an entry level plasma with no "smarts", no internet connection, no 3D, but an awesome picture.It really looks a lot bigger in person as I was afraid it would be too small for my living room but it looks great replacing a 32" CRT that served me well but was increasingly the odd man out in a digital world. The bezel on the TV is very thin so almost all of the TV itself is pure digital picture which makes it fill up a room nicely. The TV is not heavy and the remote is easy to use.I immediately set the picture settings according to some other knowledgeable owners that have found the perfect video settings and was FLOORED by the clarity despite it only being a 720p HDTV. Of course I am feeding it pure OTA HD signal (free!) via antenna and have my trusty Roku hooked up via HDMI for HD movies and programming. I also bought a cheap Blu-Ray ($67 Panasonic DMP-BD75)to watch my huge DVD collection and the occasional "wow" Blu-Ray (Avatar) that I would want to own. I streamed Tron Legacy on my Roku as a 720p signal for a test and was very pleased and excited to see the detail on the uniforms, the inky blacks, and the smooth almost glass-like environments glowing in crystal clear glory.Now let me slow down for bit though, this TV is NOT the best plasma that Samsung makes nor is the best money can buy, but for the PRICE there is no equal! Please remember that this TV is perfect for consumers like myself that want quality but without the frills and the latest tech of the month that drives up the price on everything nowadays (3D, Bluetooth, SmartTV, Wi-Fi, Apps, you name it). For the price you can't go wrong, Enjoy!

Reviews.Title: Samsung 51" Plasma 720P
Reviews.Author: Andrew Morris
Reviews.Content: Where to begin?  My birthday fell on the Super Bowl this year.  I decided it was time for a new TV as my old one had crapped out.  I had originally purchased a 55" LCD.  The picture was incredible.  It was full 1080 (my first of this stature) and pixelation was nowhere to be found.  What it did have though was this new motion interpolation technology and no way of turning it completely off. If you're familiar with what I'm talking about then you know how much it sucks.  It makes everything look super fake and cheesy as if it were shot on a home video camera or entirely in front of a green screen.  This includes major hollywood movies.  They looked like crap and were completely unwatchable.  Enter the Samsung.  I returned the 55 (not Samsung) and got the Samsung 51" Plasma.  I was worried about downgrading to 720p from 1080.  Non issue.  Plasma burn in has not been an issue at all either.  For those of you wondering if this is a good TV and a good choice in the world of hi def 1080 vs 720 - I say yes it is.  It's got an awesome picture that is every bit as clear as my 1080 set was.  The only time I notice any pixelation at all is when there is smaller text in commercials and even then with my 20/15 vision I have to be making an avid effort to just stare at the outer edges of letters to notice it (who does this under normal circumstances?).  I could not be happier with this Samsung.

Reviews.Title: Simply Amazing what $649 can buy
Reviews.Author: M&A; "Mike from Long Island"
Reviews.Content: This is my second HDTV. I was so impressed with my Samsung PN42c450 that I bought last year (in my bedroom), I was trying to get it's big sister, the Samsung PN50c450 (for my living room) for several months before I gave up due to lack of availability. I then went into current mode and decided to go with the big brother and this years model, the Samsung PN51d450 instead. Sometimes, a year difference in similar TV can be a bad thing. I took the chance and I bought this based on my current research & personal needs. I am not sorry I did!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!Setting up out of the box was so simple it took me less than 10 minutes this time to get a picture on it. First of all, the way it was boxed was great. All you have to do is undo a couple of plastic releases towards the bottom of the box and the bottom of the box opens and the TV slides out safely. The TV slides onto the stand and the 8 screws went in a bit too easy. A Philips head screwdriver was used to secure the TV to the base with no problem whatsoever. The TV is so light and it lifted easily onto my electric fireplace media center in the corner of my bright livingroom.I hooked up my standard def cable box & old VCR to it through the coaxle input. I added my regular DVD player through the A/V jacks on the VCR (yeah, I know you are not supposed to hook it up that way but it plays fine that way). The TV only has 2 HDMIs (not used by me at this point)--last years model had 3 so this concerned me a bit for future needs, 2 component jacks, one of which shares the composite A/V jacks, PC input & a USB (on the side). As I said this whole process took under 10 minutes from opening the box to watching TV. The standard def picture through the cable box (Verizon FIOS) is so amazing I may never upgrade to a high def cable box. The audio is sensational and goes from 1 to 100. I'm keeping it between 10 & 25 based on outside noise & show source, etc and it feels like we are in a movie theater. Our heads are about 11-12 feet away from the TV. There is no hissing noise we noticed as others did. We are blown away by the quality of the video & sound and there was no need for us to tinker with the settings although there are tons of them should you desire. The remote is easy to use but for the most part we use the cable remote for most features and only use the TV remote for the sleep timer and the source changing.Some very, very, very minor drawbacks. First, only 2 HDMIs. Who knows what the future holds? Second, it only has one composite jack (A/V) that shares one of the 2 component jacks. It should really have one more on the side for convenience sake. Third, beware of very bright rooms & windows as this reflects off the screen and is a little bit distracting. We have a very bright livingroom with the main windows opposite the TV but we really don't notice any glare--guess we got used to it. Fourth, the base does not swival so getting to the back of the TV is not easy once you have it in place. But I can live with these minor inconveniences.This Samsung 51 inch plasma HDTV is worth triple the great $649 price we paid for it. Our friends have bigger TVs and they don't believe we don't have a high def box. Don't believe the 720 dpi knock as you can't notice any difference unless you stand 2 feet away from the TV and who would do that? Go out and get one of these today--you won't be disappointed. You can't beat the quality & price on this thing. Even if it dies in a couple of years, it is still worth it.Pros:Built-in speakers, Bright display, Inexpensive, Realistic color, Lightweight, Easy setup, Great boxingCons:Beware of very bright rooms, No swival base, Needs 1 more a/v jack, May need more HDMIs

Reviews.Title: Good Budget Flatscreen
Reviews.Author: Charles Chen "Keyboard Jockey"
Reviews.Content: After reviewing many options online and in local stores, I purchased this as a secondary television for my basement as it hit the sweet spot in terms of size, price, and features.  Delivery was through Ceva here in NJ and the very friendly delivery man helped me bring the set into my basement, unpack it, and helped me set it up to ensure that the set wasn't defective (wish I had some cash on me to give him a tip!).The set itself is aesthetically attractive -- very thin and generally light.  The setup and installation were easy to do (mounted to the base) and the general operation of the set is simple and straightforward from the inputs to the menus to the remote.As far as 720p vs 1080p, I am primarily using it with our FiOS HD cable box and I would say that for the HD channels, from the distance that I am sitting at -- about 7 feet away, it is very, very difficult to tell the difference between my 1080p LCD -- I would say nearly impossible if I didn't already know that it was 720p (the scaler will automatically resample the 1080p signal).  I also popped in a DVD I had nearby (Vicky Cristina Barcelona) to see how it looked and it looked pretty solid, even though it wasn't an HD source.  From anything more than roughly 7 feet, it looks identical to the LCD (but with better colors and black levels).  Yes, if you get up and close, you'll see that difference much more markedly, but then you should consider buying a smaller set (37" or so) to match your expected viewing distance.Additional thoughts broken down into PROS (+), CONS (-), NEUTRAL (=):---------(+) Great price(+) Beautiful set(+) Construction seems _generally_ well built and solid(+) Black levels and colors are excellent(+) Remote and menus are easy to use and navigate(+) Makes a chime when it turns on and off -- a handy feature as it let's me know when I've turned off the cable box but missed the power on the TV before walking out of the room---------(-) Glossy screen is a distraction and takes some getting used to as our primary set is a matte LCD.  Even in the basement and with recessed lights (NOT over the set), there is a strong reflection.  You have to force yourself to not look at the reflection until you adjust to it.(-) Some faint "ghosting" (or light blurring) during action/panning shots that I've noticed.  I wonder if this goes away over time with use?  If you are planning on using this for gaming, maybe you'd want to reconsider.  I guess you can't compare the "120Hz" LCDs with this "600Hz" plasma.(-) Somewhat wobbly on the base -- the base is simply secured with 4 small screws to the panel and it does wobble a bit if you press on the panel while plugging/unplugging cables, for example.---------(=) No wireless device connectivity, no USB inputs, but I generally would not expect these at this price point eitherOverall, a good purchase and I'd highly recommend this set for most general viewing purposes.  If you're sensitive to reflections, then I would highly recommend skipping this set for one with a matte screen.UPDATE: After checking again, it does indeed have a USB port on the left side. Now I need to go RTFM and figure out what it's for :D

Reviews.Title: Just don't buy it AFTER a Bravia
Reviews.Author: Chris
Reviews.Content: First off, I've got to say I bought this TV (for the living room) to replace a 40" Sony Bravia that has now been relocated to the bedroom.  Comparing it to the famous 1080 pixels of my Sony, there's no real comparison-perhaps it's just the brightness factor since I haven't changed settings yet (100 cycle), but the Bravia is by far more crisp and clear.Otherwise, Samsung has made a great TV.  The 51" for the price (around $700)  is a steal.  One problem I found besides the apparent picture quality (well, not quality-crisp factor I'd say) is the stand construction.  In 2011 I expect the TV stand to be an easy thing to utilize and connect (as in "here's the stand all ready to just snap into the TV"), not something that requires screwing in with little black screws.Overall, Samsung has the best bang for the buck.

Reviews.Title: My First HD PN51D450
Reviews.Author: C.Orona "quesoclan"
Reviews.Content: So far so good.  I cant even begin to say how long it took me to purchase a TV because of all the comments I was reading on this or that.  I finally just broke down and got this for one of the family rooms.  I still planned on getting a bigger and higher quality TV for my main room, so I was ok with getting the lower end model first.  The first and most important thing I'll say is that it's definitely worth the money.  The HD looks great.  I dont think I really have any bad thing to say.I was of course worried about that break in period that everyone talks about.  So, I did go ahead and let the TV run with the contrast and rest of the settings around 50 (based on some comments I saw on AVS Forum) for the first couple of weeks.  I mean, I watched what I wanted, but I did leave it running on lets say that Starz channel when I wasnt watching the TV.  I didnt leave it on games too long, and I didnt watch many channels with the black bars on it.  If I did, I hit the zoom mode on the TV to avoid it.  Of course you lose a little picture quality when you do that, but at least I was being safe for the time being.  It has this pixel shift option that you can set to work every minute or two minutes, which helps you feel secure about it.So in all, Im very statisfied.  I was going to consider getting a Panasonic for my next TV to compare, but I noticed the edging on the Samsung looks way smoother and since I didnt have any problems here, I'll be getting another.  maybe the 6500 model though.

He talked up the Panasonic for 5 minutes before we changed the settings and then changed his mind.Did a small break in period but after reading the threads on the AVS forums, its no longer needed on the '11 Samsung Plasma models. Plugged in my HDMI cord and went through the settings. WOW!!! Never owned a Plasma before but I am blown away at the quality. For a $700 51" Plasma this thing is amazing!Research: [...]Supposedly Best Buy can send a rep out to fine tune the picture settings as well

You do have to make sure to upgrade your firmware for the combo to work properly, but it is all on screen menues and not too bad.  No problem with set up, not too heavy.  It gets the broadcast channels easily, there are just so many broadcast channels (I didn't know there were so many), all with nothing on them, just like cable TV, so why pay for cable? Reviews.Title: It took long enough but I'm finally happy with it.
Reviews.Author: J. Mcconnell "huffmaster"
Reviews.Content: Let me start with the good part of the review, the TV is great and looks awesome.  Got a brand new blu ray player with it as well and the picture and sound are GREAT.Now the bad portion of the review.  I ordered the TV and as with all items you get from Amazon there is an estimate on when the item will be delivered.  As it got closer to the date I began tracking the item to see for sure when I'd receive it.  Long story short it made it to my city in time to be delivered "on time", but the delivery company (Home Direct) used a local agency that held the TV for 3 days without making any attempt to contact me about delivering the TV.  So I had to make contact with them and on this initial phone call they wouldn't schedule a delivery time with me, the person I was talking with insisted that someone who wasn't there would have to call me back later.  That call never came so I called back the next day.  I received no apology, nothing, it was not until I threatened calling Home Direct that they were accommodating.  After that I finally got my TV, about 3 days after they received it.Now, at this point I've taken the TV out of the box and set it up but now it's broken.  I would love to say it was damaged in shipping and lay the blame on the delivery agency but it was an internal issue.  Within 24 hours of getting the TV I called Samsung and had to schedule a tech to come out.  That soonest appointment was over a week after my call.  The tech came out, fixed the TV in no time, and now I can watch it.  It was under warranty so I didn't have to pay for the tech coming out but all of this was just a HUGE pain.Like I said earlier, I love the TV now but getting it was awful.

Reviews.Title: Great picture but it has signal drop out with HD DVR
Reviews.Author: Prof100 "I hate bad quality"
Reviews.Content: Fantastic picture and clarity.  Great value but...This HD Plasma represents a great value, but when watching HD TV it will have the signal drop out (goes black, no sound, and then reconnects and shows image info on the upper left of the screen such as 1280x720 @ 60hz).  I use Wideopenwest cable as a cable supplier.  They use Scientific America (now Cisco) 8642 HDC DVR cable boxes.  I am now on my fourth box.  Box one worked with my now dead Sony projection TV.  HD was fine.  I bought the Samsung Plasma because of the value it offered.  HD cable box 1 one drop the signal 4 times a minute.  I called my cable company out and they replaced.  HD cable box 2 worked great for 5 mos until its hard drive crashed. HD Cable Box 3 was installed and all looked good but it started dropping the signal once per hour so I called my cable company and they replaced it with Box #4.  Tech leaves and now Box 4 drops out over 30 times in less than an hour.  I have tried both HDMI and component input.  IT ONLY DROPS OUT IN HD MODE.  It is worse when using HDMI.I called Samsung customer support and they say they know they have a problem but don't yet have firmware upgrade for this model.  I own four Samsung TVs.  Two are LCD, one DLP, and one Plasma (this turkey).If you use a Cisco or Scientific American HD DVR as supplied by your cable comppany for signal input be warned .  You might be relegated to watching  TV on low resolution480i not 720p.  You might as well cancel any HD cable service or put up with the signal dropping out once a minute or more frequently. In the last ten minutes of watching ESPN2 HD the signal dropped out 12 times.

Reviews.Title: OK TV......
Reviews.Author: Toddler Teacher
Reviews.Content: Bought mine a week ago, and it is going back to B*** B** this weekend. It is an okay TV, but I bought it b/c I thought my PC could be hooked up. What they dont tell you is it is a HDMI port that can use a DVI to HDMI cable if your computer has a  DVI port, but a lot of computers have VGA (dvi is digital based, while VGA is analog) soo it was going to be more expensive to get VGA hooked to this tv than spending an extra $200 to get the 55" VIZIO that has a digital tuner (this one doesnt have), wifi capable, with apps, AND a VGA port. Yeah this one is going back. If you aren't looking for all those things, and really just want to save 200 then this is a good plasma. Just not what I want. Wish I had known this a week ago and would have saved the hassle of returning it, but live and learn =)***What I didn't like about this tv***Watching sesame street elmo and other characters were pixelized (being run through a hdmi cable, it shouldn't have been happening).This TV has a lot of glare, and even with adjusting the setting for the colors to be vivid, it  reflected everything in my den.Not the connections I want. The computer hook up is dvi to hdmi, and I planed on using a older desktop to hook up to the tv to let the kids do learning activities on it. (which was one of my big reasons for upgrading tvs).**The Better things about this TV**Even though its a 51" it is longer then wider, the 55" I have seems like it is about the same length on the bottom but taller on the sides.The sound was really good for a flat screen, I have read different people saying you need a sound bar. With this model (and the one I got to replace this one)you dont really need it.This TV is thinner then the LCD one I replaced it with.Over all it is a OK tv as I put in the title, just wasn't what I was looking for. This one was fine but if I am going to spend a lot of money on a big ticket item I am going to make sure it is exactly what I want, and this fell short.Oh and just FYI if you havent bought a plasma tv before, you arent supposed to lay them down (not even to go in your trunk to take it home) Best Buy wouldnt let me do it, but they did hold it till Papa could bring his truck that evening and bring it to our house. I hadnt read anything about that, so if you are planning on bringing it home yourself plan accordingly.Happy shopping!

Reviews.Title: Great picture quality, EXTREMELY delicate.
Reviews.Author: Efarrings
Reviews.Content: In all technical aspects, this TV is great. The sound is crisp, the color is sharp, the functionality is fantastic. However, it is incredibly easy to break... as I learned this afternoon. After only have this television for three, short weeks, my 2 year old son haphazardly threw his juice cup over his shoulder as he was running to get into some other kind of trouble. The cup hit the screen and cracked it. Over the course of six hours the crack grew, the plasma bled, and then the screen just went out completely. The cost to repair is more than the cost of the TV.As my husband and I were taking it apart to repackage it, he lightly touched the screen to lift it and it shattered again. When all was said and done, the TV screen now has five spidery cracks in it, all from relatively harmless touches.It is my personal opinion that plasma TVs are not meant for families with small, athletic children (or even with a dog that has a particularly active tail-wagging agenda). The slightest bump can yield unfavorable results and probably a few tears. I'm not saying this TV has any sort of manufactural defect, I'm just saying that when you buy plasma, you buy at your own risk.

Reviews.Title: Horrible Glare!!
Reviews.Author: Mo Mo
Reviews.Content: I just bought this tv and I turned it on and WOW this tv is bad.  My tv room is pretty normal as it just has two windows and two lamps.  However, this tv generates a ton of glare on it from the lights and ANY sunlight.  The tv is not in a particularly sunny room either.  This TV also has a very dark picture to it.  Another issue is this TV is a mirror.  When u turn it on u can see yourself in the tv.Despite all this the biggest issue with this tv is the glare.  I have heard there are different "modes" you can put the tv on.  I have not tried them yet as I just used the standard pre-sets that come with the tv when you turn it on.  I am really disappointed with this tv.  I got it for a good price but it is totally not worth it and I will be returning it.  I dont know much about plasma tv's but this one can not be in a room with ANY light or the picture suffers terribly.I am really disappointed.

This defect existed on five of these TV's in a row. if you live in mid to higher elevation This TV is crap and should not even be sold. I finally gave up on the Samsung 51" 450 and got my cash back to buy a 47" VIZIO E series LCD and couldn't be happier. There is absolutely no way I could ever recommend this 51" Samsung 450, No way at all.Samsung,Stick to your inferior cell phones, you make a crappier TV.
